body: Just a heads up - I will merge those Backblaze driver fixes and work on the requests upload_object_via_stream regression (?) in a separate PR.

#1339 which should fix this issue has been merged.

Thanks again for reporting this issue.

@Kami Okay, I got around to setting up a test OpenStack Swift server. Looks like all the proxy code is working great in trunk. I was able to upload through the proxy with both the `proxy_url` method and using the `http_proxy` environment variable. Just in case, I also tested HTTP and HTTPS Swift endpoints. ðŸ‘
@gvengel Thanks for testing and confirming :+1:

At the moment, performance seems to be much better compared to Travis CI, but that's mostly related to small / non existent build queue.

Once Github Actions CI/CD goes out of beta and more open-source projects start using it, it will likely encounter same issues with large build queues and delayed builds as Travis and Circle CI do for open source projects.

@Kami I believe I addressed all the comments. I also verified that `python setup.py install` works on a clean virtualenv. Could you please take another look and let me know if this is ready for merge? Thanks!
@yairshemla Please feel free to open a pull request with this change - we are happy to merge it.

@Kami Hi, sure. here's the PR:
https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1343

Thanks for the contribution :+1: 

Majority of the Libcloud drivers interact directly with the provider library using the ``requests`` library and primitives offered by the Libcloud so it would be good for this driver to also to that instead of utilizing ``osc_python_sdk`` client library.

This way we have more control over the code base, it works with the Libcloud test framework, etc.
Sorry for the delay. I pushed a small change (8d179ed9d5402988e4e5138aa3db51befc634274), besides that it looks good to me :+1:

@c-w a lot of changes have accumulated in trunk since the last release.

Do you want to start the work needed to get the 2.6.0 release out - https://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/committer_guide.html#making-a-release-for-release-managers?

Thanks for the contribution.

I added a test case for it (39f2841a33d34a4460b269d02fd4dbff0c5ca5a7) and merged it into trunk.

@Kami Great! Happy to help a littie bit to this great project!
Is there a date to the next release?
It's been a while since the last release so v2.6.0 will likely be out some time in the next couple of weeks.

I made some styling changes to get build to pass and merged this into trunk.

Thanks again for your contribution. In the future, if you get a chance, it would be good to add some tests for this functionality.

@Kami Great to hear, looking forward to it!
Thanks for the help.
Resolved via #1343.

Fixed, thanks for reporting this.

Not sure how we missed that.


> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/libcloud/pull/1354?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [a3334dc...d5c69ea](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/libcloud/pull/1354?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

Thanks for contributing this bug fix, I will have a look shortly.

There were indeed quite many regressions introduced when we moved to the requests library (I fixed some here https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1339, but more need to be fixed).

I had a look and the change looks good, but can you confirm that with this change, streaming upload will still work correctly (aka the whole input file won't be buffered in memory, but sent in chunks)?

Thank you for the review!

Streaming upload should not be affected as this change is about *response* streaming. But that's a good idea anyway, I will check tomorrow. I will also check streaming download and report my findings here.

I can confirm that streaming upload does not load the whole file in memory.

Streaming download is broken in this regard, but this is already the case in the trunk branch because `raw` and `stream` are both `True`, so my change does not affect streaming download. I believe this should be fixed in another pull request.

@Kami I made a mistake when recording memory usage for streaming download, and was simply misled by the 5MB chunk size. When using a smaller chunk size, it's clear that the file isn't in memory, but sent ink chunks. So I believe we're good here. ðŸ‘
Merged, thanks!

Thanks for the contribution.

I fixed the test case and merged changes into trunk. Next time please verify that tests pass after submitting a change :)

Thanks for contributing this bug fix.

I noticed the same issue exists in ``GCEProject.set_usage_export_bucket`` method so I also fixed that. In addition to that, I also added corresponding test cases and updated methods to use keyword arguments to be on the safe side - 87247f31aeb43f30981ead86be2022a5ede17905.

It's worth noting that this bug only affected methods on the ``GCEProject`` class. So you could still use a working version by accessing ``ex_`` methods directly on the driver instance class.

Resolved it by installing the following package:

pip install --user cryptography

I think that's a reasonable approach although it would be good to have a consistent API for all the operations which are async (aka involve polling).

So ideally all of those methods would take ``sync=False`` / ``ex_sync=False`` argument.

Thanks for the contribution.

As mentioned in #1356, I'm fine with this change.

And yes, ``async`` is not a great name in this context.

Operation is indeed async in a sense that we need to poll for the result. ``polling_request`` or similar would indeed be a better name :)
Merged, thanks.
Merged, thanks.

> Merged, thanks.

Glad to help! I'm working adding some async calls to other methods and will use ex_sync for those as well.

Thanks for the contribution.

This looks reasonable.

Should we fall back to including name in the request if id is not specified (aka for backward compatibility reasons or similar)?

> Should we fall back to including name in the request if id is not specified (aka for backward compatibility reasons or similar)?

Which name? The project name is left, this patch is fixing a mistake where user "domain name" was used in place of project "domain name", I don't believe this code ever worked. Btw, using both project domain name and project domain id at a same time does not work for me.

You can use either 'project domain name' or 'project domain id' in project's scope.

Fixed in https://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&revision=1869993.

Thanks for reporting this.

There is a second gpg command that needs adjusting under 'Example of a bad signature':

gpg --verify apache-libcloud-2.6.1.tar.bz2.asc

LGTM, thanks for the contribution.

Just a heads up, in the future we plan to the move to the single driver class + "region" argument approach - #1366.

@Kami , i'm aware, and was kinda disappointed when i saw the aws regions hardcoded. I put this PR in as I need it in production in a hurry. Otherwise, although my python isn't fantastic, I'll see if i find some time later on to provide the PR for #1366

@michaelsembwever I will try to have a look at moving S3 driver to single region model soon.

Sadly the code is a bit convoluted in regards to how class variables and class instance variables are used so there are some edge cases which need to be taken care correctly.

@c-w That's what I came up with - 428c3b63.

For some reason, mypy doesn't recognize driver classes (e.g. ``EC2NodeDriver`` to be a subclass of ``NodeDriver``), so the following doesn't work:

```python
EC2 = get_driver(Provider.EC2)  # type: Type[EC2NodeDriver]
Rackspace = get_driver(Provider.RACKSPACE)  # type: Type[RackspaceNodeDriver]
```

The approach I used is not ideal, but I confirmed it works.

I'm not sure why it doesn't recognize it (I didn't dig in too much yet), I assume it's something to do with scoping.

Might even need to open mypy issue / question about it, but I assume they will come back to us with that our code already relies on too much "magic" and meta programming :D
Thanks for confirming :)
@Kami could we get a new release on pypi with this fix soon, please? that would make our life easier :)

@toabctl There is no currently no ETA for the next release yet (might take some time since there are some other larger changes in trunk and some other larger changes still need to land), but in the mean time you can use version from git "git+https://github.com/apache/libcloud.git@trunk@egg=apache-libcloud".
